Yes, technology can play an essential role in finding a balance between urbanization and environmental conservation. For example, using remote sensing technology, such as satellite imagery, can help to monitor changes in natural habitats and identify areas that are at risk of destruction or degradation. Additionally, using computer modeling and simulation tools can help to evaluate different scenarios and identify the best strategies for promoting sustainable and livable cities.

Moreover, technologies like green infrastructure, sensors, and intelligent transportation systems can help reduce environmental impacts on cities. Green infrastructure like green walls, green roofs, and urban forests help reduce the heat island effect, increase infiltration of stormwater, and improve air quality. Sensors can help to monitor air and water quality in real-time to understand how urbanization impacts the environment. Intelligent transportation systems can help to optimize traffic flow and reduce transportation-related pollutants. 

Overall, Technology is not a panacea, but it can help create more sustainable and livable cities by improving our understanding and helping us to manage urbanization and environmental conservation in tandem.
